text.lat: 180.— Interim ad Miletum ingens et navalis et pedester exspectabatur exercitus. Nam Persarum duces, iunctis copiis, adversus Miletum proficiscebantur. Itaque Iones copias conscribere inceperunt. Convocato concilio placuit ne quis pedester exercitus, qui opponeretur Persis, cogeretur, sed ut muros defenderent ipsi per se Milesii: classis autem rebus omnibus instrueretur, atque quam primum ad Laden occurreret, et pugna navali decerneret. Est autem Lade parva insula, haud procul ab urbe Mileto. Erant autem Ionibus triremes trecentae quinquaginta tres. Naves vero, quas barbari habebant, erant sexcentae.
text.eng: 180.— Meanwhile, a great army, both naval and land forces, was expected at Miletus. For the leaders of the Persians, having joined forces, were advancing against Miletus. And so the Ionians began to enroll forces. It was resolved, upon assembling a council, that no land army should be raised to face the Persians but that the Milesians themselves should defend the walls; however, let the fleet be prepared in all respects, and as soon as possible come to Lade and engage in a naval battle. Lade is a small island, not far from the city of Miletus. The Ionians had three hundred and fifty-three triremes. The ships, however, that the barbarians had numbered six hundred.

text.lat: 181.— Deinde vero, ubi in Lade insula Iones convenere, conciones habitae sunt, et quum alii apud eos verba fecissent, tum Dionysius, unus e ducibus, ita locutus est: ‘Nunc quum in novaculae acie sint res nostrae, utrum liberi simus, an servi; si quidem volueritis labores suscipere, erit id quidem nunc vobis molestum, sed poteritis esse liberi hostibus superatis: sin, disciplina militari intermissa, vos otio dederitis, nullam equidem spem habeo, poenam defectionis effugere vos posse. Sed me audite, mihique vos permittite; et vobis ego polliceor hostes magnam cladem accepturos.’
text.eng: 181.— Then indeed, when the Ionians had assembled on the island of Lade, speeches were delivered, and when others had spoken among them, then Dionysius, one of the leaders, spoke thus: 'Now when our affairs are on the razor's edge, whether we are free or slaves; if indeed you wish to undertake labors, it will indeed be burdensome to you now, but you will be able to be free with the enemies overcome: but if, having abandoned military discipline, you surrender yourselves to ease, I have no expectation that you will be able to escape the punishment of rebellion. But hear me, and allow yourselves to me; and I promise you that the enemies will suffer a great defeat.'

text.lat: 182.— His auditis, Dionysio se permiserunt Iones. Tum ille quotidie, navibus longo ordine eductis, postquam remiges in discurrendo singulis navibus per binas alias exercuerat, et milites iusserat armatos in ponte stare, reliquam diei partem in ancoris tenebat. Et illi quidem ad septimum diem ei parebant; insequente vero die, quum impatientes essent talium laborum, molestiis et solis ardore lacessiti, hosce inter se sermones miscebant: ‘Cur hos exhaurimus labores? nam desipientes nosmet vano iactatori permisimus, qui tres modo naves in commune contulit. Quanto praestat, quidvis aliud, quam haec mala, pati! Agite, ne diutius huic homini pareamus!’ His dictis, nemo amplius mandata facere voluit, sed tanquam pedester exercitus, castris in insula positis, degebant in umbra, naves conscendere exercerique nolentes.
text.eng: 182.— Upon hearing this, the Ionians allowed themselves to Dionysius. Then daily, having led the ships out in a long line, after he had exercised the rowers by running the single ships through others two by two, and had ordered the soldiers to stand armed on the deck, he kept the rest of the day at anchor. And indeed up to the seventh day, they obeyed him; but on the following day, as they were unable to bear such labors, harassed by the discomforts and the heat of the sun, they muttered among themselves: 'Why do we endure these grindings? For we, foolishly, have entrusted ourselves to a vain boaster, who contributed only three ships to the common cause. How much better to suffer anything else than these evils! Come, let us no longer obey this man!' Having said this, no one wished to follow orders any longer, but like an infantry army, settling in camps on the island, they spent their time in the shade, unwilling to board and be exercised on the ships.

text.lat: 183.— Interim Persae cum classe contra progressi sunt. Tum Iones etiam naves suas longo ordine eduxerunt. Proelio commisso, nonnulli e ducibus, sublatis velis, deserta acie in fugam se receperunt. Reliqui vero, ubi plerosque socios prodere rem communem viderunt, noluerunt fugere, sed pugnarunt discurrentes per hostium naves, easque perrumpentes; donec, quum plures naves cepissent, ipsi suarum maiorem partem perdiderunt. Satis constat Ionas magno cum detrimento devictos esse. Dionysius vero, actum esse de classe intelligens, in Siciliam vela fecit; ex qua coortus praedari incepit: Graecis quidem navibus nunquam insidiatus, sed Carthaginiensibus ac Tyrrhenis.
text.eng: 183.— Meanwhile, the Persians advanced with their fleet. Then the Ionians also led out their ships in a long line. The battle having commenced, some of the leaders, having raised their sails, deserted the line and took to flight. The rest, however, when they saw many allies betray the common cause, did not wish to flee, but fought running through the enemy ships and breaking them; until, although they captured several ships, they themselves lost the greater part of their own. It is quite clear that the Ionians were defeated with great loss. Dionysius, understanding that all was over with the fleet, set sail for Sicily; from where he started plundering: never plotting against the Greek ships, but against the Carthaginians and Tyrrhenians.

text.lat: 184.— Persae, victis pugna navali Ionibus, terra marique Miletum oppugnarunt, et, suffossis muris, admotisque cuiusque generis machinis, cum ipsa arce ceperunt, sexto a defectione Aristagorae anno; captamque in servitutem redegerunt. Ita ea ipsa calamitate devicta urbs Miletus est, quae in illam oraculo praedicta erat.
text.eng: 184.— The Persians, having defeated the Ionians in the naval battle, attacked Miletus by land and sea, and having undermined the walls and brought up machines of every kind, they took it with the citadel itself, in the sixth year from the defection of Aristagoras; and they reduced it to slavery. Thus the city of Miletus was conquered with that very calamity, which had been predicted for it by the oracle.

text.lat: 185.— Quum enim Argivi Delphorum oraculum de suae urbis salute consuluissent, alia de Argivis, alia de Milesiis edidit Pythia. Quae vero ad Miletum attinebant, haecce erant:— Tunc quoque, commentrix operum Milete malorum, Permultis coena et praestantia munera fies, Crinitisque pedes tua pluribus abluet uxor; Templi aliis nostri in Didymis sua cora manebit. Tunc igitur haec Milesiis acciderunt, quando virorum maior pars interfecta est a Persis longos capillos alentibus, et templum in Didymis exspoliatum igne concrematum est.
text.eng: 185.— For when the Argives had consulted the oracle of Delphi about their city's safety, Pythia issued different prophecies about the Argives and the Milesians. But concerning Miletus, these were the words:— Then also, Miletus, the contriver of evil works, You shall become a dinner for many people and splendid gifts will you be, And your wife will wash the feet of many long-haired men; Our temple at Didyma will keep its fate. Then these things happened to the Milesians, when the greater part of the men were killed by the long-haired Persians, and the temple at Didyma was spoiled and burnt with fire.

text.lat: 186.— Athenienses autem et aliis multis modis monstraverunt, quantum ea Mileti expugnatione luctum perceperint; et, quum Phrynichus, poeta praeclarus, drama scripsisset docuissetque, de Mileti expugnatione, in lacrimas eruperunt omnes spectatores, et mille drachmis multatus est poeta, quod domesticarum calamitatum mentionem fecisset; et lege prohibitum est, ne quis amplius hoc dramate uteretur.
text.eng: 186.— The Athenians, however, showed in many different ways how much grief they felt over Miletus's capture; and when Phrynichus, a famous poet, had written and presented a drama about the capture of Miletus, all the spectators burst into tears, and the poet was fined a thousand drachmas for having mentioned the domestic calamities; and it was prohibited by law for anyone to use this drama anymore.
Failure of Mardonius’ expedition against Greece.

text.lat: 187.— Darius ob incensas Sardes poenam de Atheniensibus et Eretriensibus sumere constituit. Magnis igitur copiis Mardonium praefecit. Hic navem ipse conscendit, et cum reliquis navibus profectus est: pedestrem vero exercitum alii duces ad Hellespontum duxerunt. Primum Thasios classe aggressi, qui ne manus quidem contra illos sustulerant, sibi subiecerunt: tum pedestri exercitu Macedonas sub iugum miserunt. Dein Athon montem navibus circumvehi instituerunt. Sed maxima coorta tempestate, maximus navium numerus ad montem illisus est. Aiunt trecentas ex navibus periisse, et hominum amplius viginti millia. Pedestrem vero exercitum noctu aggressi Thraces, magnum militum numerum occiderunt. Itaque Mardonius, turpiter re gesta, copias in Asiam ducere coactus est.
text.eng: 187.— Darius, due to the burning of Sardis, decided to exact punishment on the Athenians and Eretrians. He therefore appointed Mardonius over large forces. He himself boarded a ship, and set out with the remaining ships: the other leaders led the land army to the Hellespont. First, they attacked the people of Thasos with the fleet, who did not even raise a hand against them and were subdued: then they subjected the Macedonians with a land army. Then they attempted to sail around Mount Athos with ships. But with a great storm arising, a very large number of ships were dashed against the mountain. They say three hundred ships perished, and more than twenty thousand men. The Thracians, however, attacked the land army by night and killed a large number of soldiers. Therefore Mardonius, having conducted the matter disgracefully, was forced to lead his forces into Asia.
